title: Line signaling
text:
Line signaling is a class of <a href="telecommunications">telecommunications</a> <a href="Signaling%20%28telecommunication%29">signaling</a> <a href="Communications%20protocol">protocols</a>. Line signaling is responsible for <a href="off-hook">off-hook</a>, <a href="ringing%20signal">ringing signal</a>, answer, <a href="ground%20start">ground start</a>, <a href="on-hook">on-hook</a> unidirectional supervision messaging in each direction from <a href="calling%20party">calling party</a> to <a href="called%20party">called party</a> and vice versa. After an off-hook, line signaling initiates <a href="register%20signaling">register signaling</a> to accomplish the exchange of <a href="telephone%20number">telephone number</a>s of called party and in more modern line-signaling protocols, the calling party as well. While register signaling occurs, line signaling remains quiescent unless the calling party goes on-hook or an abnormal cessation of the call occurs, such as due to equipment malfunction or shutdown or due to <a href="telecommunications%20network">network</a> outage upstream in that call-attempt's series of spanned trunks.
Line signaling can be conveyed in a single <a href="DS0">DS0</a> channel of a <a href="trunking">trunk</a>. In modern <a href="Pulse-code%20modulation">PCM</a> telecommunications, line signaling is represented by the ABCD bits in DS0 #16 of an <a href="E-carrier">E1</a> or a selected DS0 within a <a href="Digital%20Signal%201">T1</a>.
Line signaling can also be conveyed within the channels being supervised, as in the original T1 scheme which used one out of every eight bits for supervision, or with <a href="Robbed-bit%20signaling">robbed bits</a> of a <a href="superframe">superframe</a> format, or as <a href="in-band%20signaling">in-band signaling</a>, e.g. as in L1 signaling where 2280 Hz tone pulses are used.
